posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked:
So, powering a robot using an extension cord instead of mains power. At a recent outreach event I noticed we were frequently running out of batteries, often killing old ones by overdraining them. I wondered if it would be better to simply plug the robot into the wall rather than relying on batteries.

The first thing I considered was the spike in current draw. Most wall outlets in the U.S. operate on a 15A breaker at 120V, providing 1800 watts. FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) robots typically run on a nominal voltage of around 13V. Calculating the required current, 1800W divided by 13V equals approximately 138.46A. While this is theoretically within the 120A limit for FRC competitions under constant load, during normal operation, the current draw exceeds these limits significantly.

For an outreach event, it seems feasible to keep current draw below 138A with appropriate settings. However, I'm unsure if the motors react negatively when power is returned to the system via an AC-to-DC converter. I may need to verify this assumption.

What do you think? Has anyone successfully used mains power to operate a robot? If yes, how was it implemented?

link_counts.title: Using Extension Cord / Wall Power to Run Robot for Testing?

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: I’m going to take a different approach: Marine batteries, specifically 12V >18AH batteries, marked for outreach-only use. If your project solely involves outreach, consider setting up additional capacity to avoid frequent battery replacements. However, this may require more robot space, though it’s achievable.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked: If you're working your robot as hard as match play at an outreach event, you may be overcomplicating things. Especially if there's a cord attached. Solar panels charge the battery, which powers the inverter—whether it's pumping water or running another device. Perhaps you don't need such a powerful charger, and sticking with a 10A setup could extend your robot's runtime considerably. However, those hefty, high-current chargers aren't worth it—they end up being quite large and heavy.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
Running a robot continuously (i.e., with sufficient batteries to always operate) would drain the drive motors within an hour when using older brushed CIM systems. I understand this remains a limitation.  

Currently, I have a TUNS300F12 power supply, which is among the most compact 12VDC units available; it offers 25A of current, similar in size to an Altoids tin. By fitting six of these into a battery enclosure with appropriate cooling, you could achieve 150A of output. These supplies are 85% efficient, so they should work well with a 120V 15A circuit. Additionally, purchasing them for around $200 each makes them cost-effective to keep a battery in parallel, though logistical challenges remain with the new 12/3 cable required now.  

It’s worth noting that 13V is too high; most robots operate on 12.8V batteries after adjusting for surface charge. The 120A breaker used in FIRST Robotics Competitions (FRC) matches the energy consumption of a robot over time, as I’ve never experienced a power outage during extensive practices. Therefore, maintaining a parallel battery ensures consistent power supply as long as the average draw stays under 120A.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked: You could easily connect 6 of those in a battery-powered container with appropriate heat sinking to handle 150A. Remember to do your homework before attempting such configurations; hooking multiple independent switch-mode supplies in parallel without proper configuration can result in problematic issues. For more details, refer to [this article](https://www.digikey.com/en/articles/properly-configure-parallel-power-supplies).

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked: I am assuming OP would investigate before spending $1200 on DC power supplies. The correct solution is probably among the options available at Jameco, even though they come in a larger size than expected. But 'correct' isn't really accurate.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Put a Shottky or active rectifier on the output of your power supply and feed a 12V supercapacitor module. Put a 12V incandescent auto clearance lamp across the supercapacitor. Bonus points for an appropriate breaker. Braking on brushless motors can push significant energy back and either make your DC power supply unhappy, shut down in protest, or fry.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: That looks awesome! Do you mind sharing more info about what I am seeing here?

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: Braking on brushless motors can push significant energy back and either make your dc power supply unhappy/shut down in protest/fry. Do you think adding some parallel diodes to clamp the voltage to battery levels would be enough? Now that I think about it, has anyone tried that in actual competition to protect a limelight or other sensitive devices? Would be pretty good to free up our VRM from that.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: You can’t clamp it with simple diodes. You can do that with a solenoid because you know where the inductive kick comes from and you can put the diode after the switch. You could build up an active zener with a serious power transistor that could do the clamping. Using a diode and a significant capacitor is a better method if you are trying to kill the peak. Add a resistor across the diode to keep the capacitor voltage near battery voltage when its not active. A power zener or an active zener/clamp circuit across the capacitor would be smart too. Though with normal capacitors is easy enough to buy them in 24 Volt rating. Calculating the energy clipping capacity needed is probably do-able, but it depends on a LOT of things, many of which we only know roughly.

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: Ideally, I think you’d want something like this but appropriate size for FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) motors: ODrive Regen Clamp – ODrive Robotics

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
On my unit, I'm using an active rectifier module, also known as an ideal diode. It has additional smart features along with a normal diode and a large MOSFET. When power is initially passed through the diode, it charges a capacitor. The smart component then activates the MOSFET, reducing the forward voltage across the diode nearly to zero. The capacitor's voltage decreases gradually. Once it drops too low, the MOSFET shuts off, and the capacitor recharges using the diode's voltage drop.

I purchased this model: [link]. Another version includes a ground terminal for continuous operation but has more limitations compared to the first.

A large shottky rectifier could work, providing approximately 11.9 volts on a 12-volt supply. A regular large diode might suffice, delivering around 11.3 volts.

This supercapacitor module requires critical balancing circuitry; avoid unintended shorts. These modules can handle high currents like melting wires.

The 83-Amp power supply is sensitive to certain conditions, shutting down in protest during operation. Be cautious with applications involving high current outputs, as they may melt small wires or cause issues.

For the dimmer bulb, ensure the output drops to zero when turned off. It serves as a useful indicator of operation. Obtain it from your local auto parts store. Navigating the frame ground can be challenging; consider seeking a module with two actual wires if possible.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Yes. The power supplies intended for parallel use incorporate circuitry to ensure shared output current distribution. Standard off-the-shelf power supplies lack this feature. The output voltage tolerance is dictated by the precision of the voltage reference in the controller chips, typically ranging from ±1% to ±5%, making it nearly certain that the power supplies won’t share the output current effectively. A past incident involved a coworker improperly configuring three paralleled power supplies, leading to inefficient load sharing and ensuing complications.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Understanding resistor selection is crucial for effective braking systems. The three key parameters are resistance, power rating, and energy rating. Peak power rating relates to energy, so identifying the appropriate resistor based on these specifications is vital. Heat sinks require the resistor's peak current to stay below 80 Amps, necessitating a minimum resistance of 0.15 Ohms, equating to a maximum power dissipation of 960 Watts. Instead of assuming a 1kW resistor, wirewound resistors are preferred due to their ability to handle short bursts of higher power. Using four 0.8 Ohm resistors in parallel provides redundancy and protects against failure. Current sense resistors, typically 0.1 Ohm, can be configured in series or parallel for optimal performance. Specialized braking resistors are designed for high-energy applications, though some may not meet 12V operational needs. Calculating energy dissipation involves accounting for the system's kinetic energy, aiming for efficient energy transfer rather than loss. Alternative strategies include stead loads, where steady-state power is wasted during pulses. For tethered robots, speed limitations apply, whereas flywheels and elevators can reach full speed. Advanced resistors with energy ratings offer solutions for extreme conditions, such as 500 Amp pulses at 5kV, requiring careful current control to prevent damage. For further details, refer to the PDF guide available at [vishay.com](https://www.vishay.com/docs/49076/_wirewound_resistors_pulse_handling_capabilities_vmn_pl0396_1604.pdf).

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked: For continuous robot operation, a Y connector is added to the robot side along with hot-swappable batteries to maintain functionality. In a bench setup, connecting two batteries in parallel provides sufficient power. This method is surprisingly affordable and straightforward. Contrary to common belief, connecting dissimilar batteries in parallel is more common than perceived, especially when auxiliary batteries are involved. Lead-acid batteries are preferred due to their forgiving nature, though alternatives may vary.
